author: news.sky
title: What Is A Northern Powerhouse Anyway?
text:
The Chancellor has staked his political reputation on creating a Northern Powerhouse as part of the one-nation Conservatism but what does it all mean? :: What is a Northern Powerhouse? It sounds like an appliances warehouse. 
Northern Powerhouse: the appliance of economic science
It's not. It's about the rebalancing of the UK economy pushing growth outside London in the Northern cities. One-nation Government.
The theory is that by improving the "connectivity" between the cities of Manchester, Leeds, Hull, Sheffield and Liverpool (ie better transport links) a super economic power will be created.
That and a shed load of investment, which Mr Osborne has recently been trying to secure from the Chinese.
In Mr Osborne's words: "We need a Northern Powerhouse too.
"Not one city, but a collection of northern cities - sufficiently close to each other that combined they can take on the world."
And then he gave a football analogy to make it very clear - because that's what football analogies do.
"You know, if you brought together the best players from each of the Premiership teams in the north, you’d have a team that would wipe the floor with any competition.
"We need to bring the cities of the north together as a team – that’s how Britain will beat the rest."
:: Whose idea was it? 
Osborne: "100% focused on delivering the Northern Powerhouse"
Mr Osborne would like you to think it was Mr Osborne's idea.
But it was cribbed from obscure Labour policy papers – ones the party itself failed to take up.
To the Chancellor's credit, he forged it in Government policy and staked his personal reputation on it.
:: When did it appear in the political lexicon? 
George Osborne makes his June 2014 speech
He made his "we need a northern powerhouse" speech on 23 June 2014 at the Museum of Science and Industry, Manchester. Then.
It's been a key plank of one-nation Conservatism ever since and the party's pitch to hard-working families.
:: Why does Osborne love the North? Isn't he a Londoner? 
Osborne's Tatton seat
Strictly speaking yes but he is the first Chancellor to represent a seat in the North in 35 years.
As he told the June 2014 gathering: "As you can tell from my accent, I wasn’t brought up here. I was born and raised in London."
Aside from the seat, it's politically expedient to romance voters north of the border, where there has been growing disillusion with Labour.
And the Labour-led councils love his plans. In fact, they are right at the centre of them.
:: So what is the Chancellor actually going to do? 
Ultimo founder Michelle Mone has a role to play
£13bn of investment, largely in transport. First there's HS2 connecting the North with the South and then there's HS3 – the East-West link.
There are 40 major road schemes planned and an Oyster card system for public transport between the "powerhouse" cities.
Michelle Mone, Ultimo (bras) founder, is leading an independent review into encouraging business start-ups in disadvantaged communities.
:: Isn't it all really just about Manchester? 
All roads do not lead to Manchester
The Government's a bit touchy about this.
It is very keen to stress that the vision is not just about Manchester but the other northern cities.
At the end of last week, the Chancellor announced that, like Manchester, Sheffield would become a combined authority with an elected mayor.
No question though, Manchester is the big hitter – it has a higher population and number of jobs.
:: And can the North really "take on the world"? 
Northern football teams would wipe the floor with the rest of the world
The Northern Powerhouse region, accounts for 16.7% of the UK population and 13.3% of the UK's Gross Value Added – compared to London's 24.5%, according to the Centre for Cities .
It has performed below the UK average for 10 years.
The Centre for Economics and Business Research has suggested it is not going to fulfil Mr Osborne's hoped-for potential.
It suggested the gap between London and the north of England will rise to £110bn (94%) in the next 10 years.
The northern football teams, however...
